This is where Java edition users ask for custom worlds back because that was a good feature that was removed for a much more limited and less good version of the same thing...

I agree completely.

I don't understand how this was even considered. Iron or has always been harder to find than it should have been. Why on earth was it DOWNgraded when it should have been UPgraded?

The change made in 21w10a needs to be reverted. Otherwise, the game is unplayable early on. The concept that this makes leather more valuable early on is laughable. Leather is even harder to come by. If the idea is to make iron armor harder to get is desired, then hit THAT target by changing the villager armorsmiths who practically give away iron armor pieces. See https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360075787692-Armorsmith-Chainmail-vs-Iron-.

IF this change is kept in the release, it will force me to stop playing Minecraft entirely. I love this game, so I would hate to have that happen. But without buckets, hoppers, and iron tools, the early game is unplayable. This MUST be fixed.

I've done some more digging (literally), and I think I understand why they're doing it this way:

The have expanded the world by sixty-four levels downward and 128 upward. As a result, they had to spread out the distributions of the various ores, probably in an attempt to keep from overloading the world. See https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Java_Edition_1.17 and especially https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/File:21w10a_approximate_ore_distribution.jpg.

But, they made a huge mistake with iron. Iron now doesn't spawn sufficiently until you get down to level 16, and it only rarely spawns when exposed to air. Iron is just too critical in the early game for this to be viable. Buckets, hoppers, and some iron tools are simply required early on.

They need to fatten up the range of iron levels towards the top, and totally eliminate the "not next to air" restriction.

There is one potential saving grace coming: mountains. The distribution picture (see link above) clearly shows plentiful iron up at altitudes above 128, peaking at level 256. Unfortunately, that only will be a factor in Mountain biomes, and those haven't been included in the current snapshot (yet).

So, my bottom line is that it's an understandable change, but I think they leapt way too far with it. They need to find a way to get this critical resource into the hands of players earlier than it is. It probably won't keep me from playing it, but it certainly has put a damper on my evangelism for the game. And THAT costs them $$$.

Gold drops at least three times more than iron. This is Microsoft being cruel because they can, but really. What good are all the new things you add if we can never get there? I've never made a potion. I've never created a book. I've never taken a tower. No - I just dig for armor/iron so I can leave my cave. What a stupid game run by (literally a completely apt description) moroonic assjoles.

It's actually a huge breath of fresh air in my opinion.

here's a explanation why its built like this. This is built for both windows and mobile phones and mobile devices can only use the on screen ui. So it would be impossible for mobile players to change it as this is built for both sides
Good idea, I'll support it. I'd love to see customizable shields be added in, as well!

agreed, Especially since there's a delay from the moment you crouch to when the shield actually goes up, which is really annoying

I 've seen people argue that this is because of Mobile which have to use UI buttons, but in my opinion, it'd be better if the ''eat'' button was replaced with a ''block'' button when you had the shield in your hand, that way the screen doesn't get too crowded

 

still though, you could just add ''shield block'' as an optional keybind in other platforms, that way they don't have to be limited to crouching the same way mobile is

They can't because mobile players use bedrock too and this would make it difficult to block on phones and ipads.

This is also why bedrock for console and laptop is so buggy and has the processing speed of a phone.

The only real way to fix this is to remove mobile players from bedrock, so that bedrock players dont have to play with the same parameters and mechanics as phone players, this would also solve many other issues like processing speed, redstone mechanics, etc.

But minecraft doesn't want to lose money by removing mobile players, or even by making a new platform for minecraft just for mobile, so don't expect them to fix the shield or the countless other issues with bedrock.

They're probably just saying "go to java if bedrock sucks so bad", but some of us can't afford a laptop and are stuck on console, and some of us can't afford buying minecraft when we already have it on console, so yeah, bedrock sucks.
I was just about to write about this idea in an article but now I'm very interested, what other ideas do you have?

Aren’t java and bedrock owned by different companies (java by Mojang) (bedrock by Microsoft).
And how would the Mojang account work?
I was just about to write this. All my friends are in a Java SMP server together and I feel left out. But I can’t afford a pc. I wish they would just become one massive version together.

As someone who has played Bedrock for many years (and also Java for many years), I like the idea about better redstone and servers for Bedrock, along with adding hardcore and spectator. Amplified worlds probably won't be added, because Bedrock is also played on mobile. If Mojang adds it, there should be a warning, telling people to be careful if they are playing on mobile or an old/not good PC. Also, I like idea of RTX for Java. The main reason why there isn't crossplay between Minecraft Java and Minecraft Bedrock, is because they are in different computer languages. Java is coded in Java (obviously), but Bedrock is coded in C++. No, you can't just change what the game is coded in, unfortunately.

This is all well and good, but like it has already been said by Mojang, you will never be able to achieve true parity.

This is because (among other things) as SlickBike211974 has already pointed out, the two versions are coded in completely different languages and unintended behaviour will not be the same so server and client will not agree on what happens. 

Also RTX for Java will probably not happen, because the rendering engine doesn't support Pathfinding (the Raytracing type you see in Bedrock with reflections and stuff).
